moves.1. c4 Nf6: I almost never face the English, but it is far from my known ground. I'd like to transpose to my favourite Q defence, but...
moves.3. d3 c5: ...this first, it can't be bad. The N's penetration in b5 can be controlled with a6.
moves.4. Nf3 Nc6 5. g3 Qc7: This was in order to break the natural lines. It invites Nb4, and supports e5.
moves.6. Bg2 e5: I wanted to play this, knowing it is a loss of tempo, trying to make him think in an opening that obviously he masters.
moves.7. O-O d6 8. Bg5: I already don't like my asset, but hey, let's see what can I do with it. Now BxN would be annoying.
moves.8... Nh5: planning to win the tempo with h6. This B is without scope here, right now.
moves.9. Nd5: This is the backfire. My Q has few squares.
moves.9... Qd7: This is ugly. But now, let's try white to get a concrete advantage.
moves.10. a3: Well done, since I was planning Nb4.
moves.10... Ne7: I threat the exchanges that will favour me the most.
moves.11... f5: I have to "do something"or he will just squeeze me in to death.
moves.13. Nh4: White threats QxN, followed by Nf6+, forking my Q.
moves.13... Nxd5: ...abandoning one defender of f5, but I can't allow this N to stay there. I have to release my Q.
moves.16. b4: The problem with b6 is Qa4+.
moves.16... Be7: A good developin move, threatening BxN, opening the K.
moves.17. Ng2: ...which he prevents. For some reason, he has not taken on f5... :-)
moves.17... Bd7: Preventing the Q's entrance. Of course, I am allowing bxc5...
moves.18. Ne3: Repositioning his N on a nice square, pressing f5.
moves.19. Bc3: Well, obviously. Again, it's now or never.
moves.19... f4: This will have the effect to avoid the opening of the f column in the exchanges. Of course he can play 20. Be6, Qf8...
moves.20. Ng4 Bd7: If he plays Nf6+ he will just lose it. I won't take g3, of course.
moves.21. bxc5: The "pending question". I'll take the tempo to do something.
moves.21... f3: I can now think in BxN, BxB, Rf8...but I overlooked the weakness of e5 after the second take. Nothing I could have done about it, neither...
moves.22... Bxd6 23. Nxe5: ...but this is even worse. My Q is not completely lost, but obviously the game will be his soon. So I planned a crazy, crazy idea, being sure he won't have fallen for it... (Alternative moves were: 23... BxN, 24. BxB, o-o!?...
moves.23... Nf4: I calculated he will think about an overlook from my part, or even a silly NxB+.
moves.24. Nxf7 Ne2+: Well, he won't lose the Q, right?
moves.25. Kh1 Bxh3: Now, the crucial moment: Will he "see" this very unusual mate pattern? He can still save the game with Rg1 - very simple, and then it's doubtful black has any hope. But my opponent was too hungry...
